question: Question 1 A single-phase 100 kVA, 1000 V / 100 V, 50 Hz transformer has a voltage drop of 5% across its series impedance at full load. Of this, 3% is due to resistance.  The percentage regulation of the transformer at full load with 0.8 lagging power factor is
solution: Percent voltage regulation [latex]=\left ( \frac{I_2R_{02}}{E_2} \times 100 \right )\cos \phi _2\pm \left ( \frac{I_2X_{02}}{E_2} \times 100 \right ) \sin \phi _2 [/latex] [latex]\% \; VR.=V_r \cos \phi _2\pm V_x \sin \phi _2 [/latex] (where, '+' lag p.f. and '-' lead p.f.) At full load: Given,  [latex]V_r=3\% [/latex] Impedance drop, [latex]V_z=5\% [/latex] [latex]\therefore \;[/latex] Reluctance drop, [latex]V_x=\sqrt{5^2-3^2}=4\% [/latex] Voltage regulation at full load at 0.8 p.f. lagging [latex]V.R.=3(0.8)+4(0.6)=4.8\%[/latex]

question: Question 2 In a salient pole synchronous motor, the developed reluctance torque attains the maximum value when the load angle in electrical degrees is
solution: Salient pole synchronous motor power and torque relations per phase: [latex]P=\frac{E_bV}{X_t}\sin \delta +\frac{V^2}{2}\left ( \frac{X_d-X_q}{X_dX_q} \right ) \sin (2\delta ) \;Watts [/latex] [latex]T=\frac{60}{2 \pi N_S}\left [ \frac{E_bV}{X_d} \sin \delta + \frac{V^2}{2}\left ( \frac{X_d-X_q}{X_dX_q} \right ) \sin (2\delta ) \right ]\; N-m[/latex] The second term is reluctance power or reluctance torque, which is directly proportional to [latex]\sin 2\delta[/latex]. Therefore, reluctance torque will be maximum. When,  [latex]\delta =45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]\because \;\;\sin2 (45^{\circ})\Rightarrow \sin 90^{\circ}=1[/latex] (Maximum)

question: Question 3 A single phase fully controlled rectifier is supplying a load with an anti-parallel diode as shown in the figure. All switches and diodes are ideal. Which one of the following is true for instantaneous load voltage and current?

Question 4 Four power semiconductor devices are shown in the figure along with their relevant
terminals. The device(s) that can carry dc current continuously in the direction shown when
gated appropriately is (are)

Question 5 Two wattmeter method is used for measurement of power in a balanced three-phase load
supplied from a balanced three-phase system. If one of the wattmeters reads half of the
other (both positive), then the power factor of the load is
solution: In two wattmeter method, [latex]\tan \phi =\frac{\sqrt{3}(W_1-W_2)}{W_1+W_2} [/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given}, \; W_2 &=\frac{W_1}{2} \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{\sqrt{3}\left (W_1-\frac{W_1}{2} \right ) }{\left (W_1+\frac{W_1}{2} \right )} \\ \phi &= 30^{\circ}\\ \cos \phi &=\cos 30^{\circ}=0.866 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 Consider a lossy transmission line with [latex]V_{1} \; and  \; V_{2}[/latex] as the sending and receiving end voltages, respectively. Z and X are the series impedance and reactance of the line, respectively. The steady-state stability limit for the transmission line will be
solution: With only x: [latex]P_{max}=\left | \frac{V_1V_2}{x} \right |[/latex] With Lossy Tr, Line [latex]P=\left | \frac{V_1V_2}{z} \right | \cos (\beta -\delta )-\left | \frac{AV_2^2}{z} \right |\cos (\beta -\delta )[/latex] Therefore, with Lossy Line [latex]P_{max} \lt \left | \frac{V_1V_2}{x} \right |[/latex]

question:
Question 7 The graph of a network has 8 nodes and 5 independent loops. The number of branches of
the graph is

Question 8 In the figure, the voltages are [latex]v_{1}(t)=100cos(\omega t)[/latex], [latex]v_{2} (t) = 100cos(\omega t + \pi /18)[/latex] and [latex]v_{3}(t) = 100cos(\omega t + \pi /36)[/latex]. The circuit is in sinusoidal steady state, and [latex]R \lt \lt \omega L[/latex]. [latex]P_{1}[/latex],[latex]P_{2}[/latex] and [latex]P_{3}[/latex] are the average power outputs. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: [latex]V_2:\frac{\pi}{18}=\frac{180^{\circ}}{18}=10^{\circ} [/latex] [latex]V_3:\frac{\pi}{36}=\frac{180^{\circ}}{36}=5^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]V_2[/latex] leads [latex]V_1 [/latex] and [latex]V_3[/latex], So, [latex]V_2[/latex]is a source, [latex]V_1[/latex] and [latex]V_3[/latex] are absorbing. Hence, [latex]P_2 \gt 0[/latex] and [latex]P_1,P_3 \lt 0[/latex]

question:
Question 9 Match the transfer functions of the second-order systems with the nature of the systems
given below.
solution: [latex]P=\frac{15}{s^2+5s+15} [/latex] [latex]\omega _n=\sqrt{15}=3.872[/latex] rad/sec [latex]  2 \xi \times 3.872=5 [/latex] [latex]\xi=\frac{5}{2 \times 3.872}=0.64 \;\;\;\;(Underdamped) [/latex] [latex]Q=\frac{25}{s^2+10s+25} [/latex] [latex]\omega _n=\sqrt{25}=5 [/latex] rad/sec [latex]2 \xi \times 5=10[/latex] [latex] \xi=1 \;\;\;\;\;(Critically \; damped) [/latex] Observing all the options, option (C) is correct.

question:
Question 10 A positive charge of 1 nC is placed at (0,0,0.2) where all dimensions are in metres.
Consider the x-y plane to be a conducting ground plane. Take [latex]\epsilon _{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12}[/latex] F/m. The z component of the E field at (0,0,0.1) is closest to
solution: Net electric field at point P due to charge Q is, [latex]\begin{aligned} \vec{E_{12}}&=\frac{Q\vec{R_{12}}}{4 \pi \varepsilon _0|\vec{R_{12}}|^3} \\ &= \frac{1 \times 10^{-9}(-0.1\hat{a_z})}{4 \pi (8.854 \times 10^{-12})(0.1)^3}\\ &+ \frac{-1 \times 10^{-9}(-0.3\hat{a_z})}{4 \pi (8.854 \times 10^{-12})(0.3)^3}\\ &= \left [ \frac{-10^5}{4 \pi (8.854)}- \frac{10^5}{4 \pi (8.854)9} \right ]\hat{a_z}\\ &=(-898.774-99.863) \hat{a_z}\\ &= -999.09\hat{a_z}\; V/m \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 11 Let f be a real-valued function of a real variable defined as [latex]f(x)=x^{2}[/latex] for [latex]x \gt 0[/latex], and[latex] f(x)=-x^{2}[/latex] for [latex]x \lt 0[/latex]. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} f(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} x^2 & x \geq 0\\ -x^2 & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ f'(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 2x & x \geq 0\\ -2x & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right.\\ f''(x)&=\left\{\begin{matrix} 2 & x \geq 0\\ -2 & x \lt 0 \end{matrix}\right. \end{aligned}[/latex] The first derivation of f (i.e) f'(x) is not derivable at x=0.

options.B: f(x) is continuous but not differentiable at x=0
options.C: f(x) is differentiable but its first derivative is not continuous at x=0
options.D: f(x) is differentiable but its first derivative is not differentiable at x=0

question:
Question 12 The value of the directional derivative of the function [latex]\phi (x,y,z)=xy^{2}+yz^{2}+zx^{2}[/latex] at the
point (2,-1,1) in the direction of the vector [latex]p=i+ 2j + 2k[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \phi &= xy^2+yz^2+zx^2\\ \bigtriangledown \phi &=\bar{i}\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial x}+\bar{j}\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial y} +\bar{k}\frac{\partial \phi }{\partial z} \\ &=\bar{i}(y^2+2xz)+\bar{j}(2xy+z^2)\\&+\bar{k}(2yz+x^2) \\ \bigtriangledown \phi _{(2,-1,1)} &= \bar{i}(1+4)+\bar{j}(-4+1)+\bar{k}(-2+4)\\ &= 5\bar{i}-3\bar{j}+2\bar{k}\\ \bar{P} &= \bar{i}+2\bar{j}+2\bar{k}\\ |\bar{P}|&=\sqrt{1+4+4}=3 \end{aligned}[/latex] THe directional derivative of f(x,y,z) at (2,-1,1) in the direction of [latex]\bar{P}[/latex] is [latex]\bigtriangledown \phi _{at \; P} \cdot \frac{\bar{P}}{|\bar{P}|}= (5\bar{i}-3\bar{j}+2\bar{k})\left ( \frac{\bar{i}+2\bar{j}+2\bar{k}}{3} \right )=\frac{5-6+4}{3}=1[/latex]

question: Question 13 The value of the integral [latex]\oint_{c} \frac{z+1}{z^{2}-4}dz[/latex] in counter clockwise direction around a circle C of radius 1 with center at the point z=-2 is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\int \frac{z+1}{z^2-4}dz\\ &\int \frac{z+1}{(z-2)(z+2)}dz\\ &\int \frac{\frac{z+1}{z-2}}{z+2}dz \;\; \text{where, } f(z)=\frac{z+1}{z-2}\\ &=2 \pi i f(-2)\\ &=2 \pi i \left ( \frac{-2+1}{-2-2} \right )\\ &= 2 \pi i \left ( \frac{-1}{-4} \right )=\frac{\pi i}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 14 In the logic circuit shown in the figure, Y is given by
Question 15 The op-amp shown in the figure is ideal. The input impedance  [latex]\frac{v_{in}}{i_{in}}[/latex] is given by
Question 16 A continuous-time input signal x(t) is an eigenfunction of an LTI system, if the output is
solution: Eigen function is a type of input for which output is constant times of input. i.e. Where, [latex]x(t)=[/latex] System input = eigen function [latex]H(s)=[/latex] transfer function of system [latex]y(t)=[/latex] system output Here, [latex]y(t)=H(s)|_{s=a}\; e^{at}=k \cdot x(t)[/latex] where, k= eigen-value =[latex]H(s)|_{s=a}[/latex] [latex]x(t)=[/latex] eigen-function input

options.A: k x(t) , where k is an eigenvalue
options.B: k [latex]e^{j\omega t}[/latex] x(t), where k is an eigenvalue and [latex]e^{j\omega t}[/latex] is a complex exponential signal
options.C: x(t) [latex]e^{j\omega t}[/latex], where [latex]e^{j\omega t}[/latex] is a complex exponential signal
options.D: k H([latex]\omega[/latex]) ,where k is an eigenvalue and H([latex]\omega[/latex]) is a frequency response of the system

question: Question 17 Consider a non-singular 2x2 square matrix A. If trace(A)=4 and trace([latex]A^{2}[/latex])=5, the determinant of the matrix A is _________(up to 1 decimal place).
solution: A is 2 x 2 matrix [latex]\begin{aligned} Tr\; A&=4\\ \lambda _1+\lambda _2&=4\\ tr(A^2)&=5\\ \lambda _1^2+\lambda _2^2&=5\\ (\lambda _1+\lambda _2)^2&=\lambda _1^2+\lambda _2^2+2\lambda _1 \lambda _2\\ 2\lambda _1 \lambda _2+5&=16\\ 2\lambda _1 \lambda _2&=11\\ \lambda _1 \lambda _2&=\frac{11}{2}\\ |A|&=\frac{11}{2}=5.5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 18 Let f be a real-valued function of a real variable defined as f (x)=x-[x], where [x]
denotes the largest integer less than or equal to x. The value of [latex]\int_{0.25}^{1.25}f(x)dx[/latex] is _______ (up to 2 decimal places).

Question 19 In the two-port network shown, the [latex]h_{11}[/latex] parameter 
(where, [latex]h_{11}=\frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}[/latex], when [latex]V_{2}[/latex] =0) in ohms
is _____________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: By KCL, [latex]\frac{V_a-1}{1}+\frac{V_a}{1}+\frac{V_a+2I_1}{1}=0 [/latex] [latex]3V_a+2I_1=1\;\;...(i)[/latex] [latex] I_1=\frac{1-V_a}{1}\;\;...(ii) [/latex] Substitute equation (ii) in equation (i) [/latex] [latex]V_a=-1 [/latex] [latex]I_1=\frac{1-V_a}{1}=\frac{1-(-1)}{1}=2 [/latex] [latex]h_{11}=\frac{V_1}{I_1}=\frac{1}{2}=0.5\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 20 The series impedance matrix of a short three-phase transmission line in phase coordinates
is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} Z_{s} & Z_{m} &Z_{m} \\ Z_{m}& Z_{s}& Z_{m}\\ Z_{m}& Z_{m}& Z_{s} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. If the positive sequence impedance is [latex](1 + j10)\Omega[/latex], and the zero
sequence is [latex](4 + j31)\Omega[/latex], then the imaginary part of [latex]Z_{m}[/latex] (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) is ______(up to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_1&=(1+j10)\Omega \\ Z_0&=(4+j31)\Omega \\ \text{we know,}\\ Z_1&=Z_s-Z_m\\ Z_0&=Z_s+2Z_m\\ Z_1-Z_0&=-3Z_m\\ Z_m&=\frac{Z_0-Z_1}{3}\\ &=\frac{4+j31-1-j10}{3}\\ &=\frac{3+j21}{3}\\ &=1+j7 \end{aligned}[/latex] The imaginary part of [latex]Z_m[/latex] is 7.00.

question:
Question 21 The positive, negative and zero sequence impedances of a 125 MVA, three-phase, 15.5 kV,
star-grounded, 50 Hz generator are j0.1 pu, j0.05 pu and j0.01 pu respectively on the
machine rating base. The machine is unloaded and working at the rated terminal voltage. If
the grounding impedance of the generator is j0.01 pu, then the magnitude of fault current
for a b-phase to ground fault (in kA) is __________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: For LG fault, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_{f\;p.u.}&=\frac{3V_{Th}}{Z_1+Z_2+Z_0+3Z_n}\\ &=\frac{3 \times 1 }{0.1+0.05+0.01+3(0.01)}\\ &=15.789\; p.u.\\ I_{base}&=\frac{P}{\sqrt{3}\cdot V_L}\\ &=\frac{125 \times 10^6}{\sqrt{3} \times 15.5 \times 10^3}\\ &=4656.05A\\ I_f&=I_{f\;p.u.}\cdot I_{base}\\ &=15.789 \times 4656.05\\ &=73516.538=73.52kA \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 22 A 1000 x 1000 bus admittance matrix for an electric power system has 8000 non-zero
elements. The minimum number of branches (transmission lines and transformers) in this
system are _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Number of buses =1000 No. of non-zero element = 8000 [latex]\begin{aligned} \% \text{ sparsity}&=\% x\\ &=\frac{\text{Number of zero element}}{\text{Total number of elements }}\\ &=\frac{10^6 -8000}{10^6}=0.992\\ \text{NO. of Tr-lines}&=\frac{N^2(1-x)-N}{2}\\ &=\frac{1000^2(1-0.992)-1000}{2}\\ &=3500 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 23 The waveform of the current drawn by a semi-converter from a sinusoidal AC voltage
source is shown in the figure. If [latex]I_0[/latex]=20 A, the rms value of fundamental component of the
current is ___________A (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} i_{s1}&=\frac{4I_0}{\pi}\cos \frac{\alpha }{2}\\ I_{s1(rms)}&=\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\pi}I_0\cdot \cos \frac{\alpha }{2}\\ &=\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\pi} \times 20 \times \cos \left ( \frac{30^{\circ}}{2} \right )\\ &=17.39A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 A separately excited dc motor has an armature resistance [latex]R_{a}= 0.05\Omega[/latex]. The field excitation is kept constant. At an armature voltage of 100 V, the motor produces a torque of 500 Nm at zero speed. Neglecting all mechanical losses, the no-load speed of the motor (in radian/s) for an armature voltage of 150 V is _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution:
Given separately initiated DC motor, Field excitaion is constant, Producing a torque of 500 N-m [latex]\begin{aligned}
&\text{At zero speed,}\\
 \because \; N&= 0,\; E_b=0\\ 
E_b &= V-I_aR_a\\ 
 0&= 100-I_a(0.05)\\ 
\therefore \; I_{a1} &=\frac{100}{0.05} =2000A\\ 
T &= \frac{60}{2 \pi N}E_bI_a\\ 
 &= \frac{60}{2 \pi N}\frac{\phi ZNP}{60A}\cdot I_a\\ 
\text{Let,}\;\; T_1&=\frac{1}{2 \pi}\frac{ZP}{A}\phi I_{a1}\;\text{N-m} \\ 
\text{Let,}\;\; T_1 &=kI_{a1} \\ 
\text{where,}\;\; k &= \frac{1}{2 \pi}\frac{ZP \phi}{A}\\ 
T_1 &= 500 \text{N-m}, \\
I_{a1}&=2000A\\
k&=\frac{500}{2000}=0.25
\end{aligned}[/latex] When motor runs on no-load given all mechanical losses neglected. No-load current is negligible and the voltage drop at no-load can be negligible. [latex]\begin{aligned}
\therefore \;\;E_b &\simeq V=150V \\ 
 E_b&= \frac{\phi ZNP}{60A}\\ 
\text{Already solved,}\\
 k&=\frac{1}{2\pi} \frac{ZP \phi }{A}\\ 
 \therefore \;\;\frac{ZP \phi }{A} &=2 \pi (k) \\ 
 \therefore \;\; E_b &= 2 \pi (k) \cdot \frac{N}{60}\\ 
\therefore \;\; E_b&= k \times \omega \\ 
(\omega : & \text{No-load speed in rad/sec})\\
\therefore \;\;\omega  &= \frac{E_b}{k}\\ 
\therefore \;\;\omega  &= \frac{150}{0.25}\\ 
\omega &= 600 \text{rad/sec}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 C onsider a unity feedback system with forward transfer function given by [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)}[/latex] The steady-state error in the output of the system for a unit-step input is _________(up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Steady state error for type-0 and step input, [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{1+k+p} [/latex] [latex]k_p=\lim_{s \to 0}\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+2)}=\frac{1}{2} [/latex] [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{2}{3}[/latex] [latex]\;\;=0.66[/latex] uinits

question: Question 26 A transformer with toroidal core of permeability [latex]\mu[/latex]  is shown in the figure. Assuming uniform flux density across the circular core cross-section of radius [latex]r\lt \lt R[/latex], and neglecting any leakage flux, the best estimate for the mean radius R is
solution:
Since we know reluctance of core: [latex]\Re =\frac{l_c}{\mu a}[/latex] Here, [latex] l_c= [/latex] mean core length, a= area of core reluctance, [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\Re &=\frac{2 \pi R}{\mu  \times \pi r^2}\\
&=\frac{2R}{\mu r^2}\\
[\text{where} R &= \text{mean radius of core}] \\ 
\text{or}\;\; R&=\frac{\Re \mu r^2}{2} \\ 

\text{and}\;\; \Re &= \frac{mmf}{flux}=\frac{N_pI_p}{\phi }\\ 
\text{Here,}\;\; \phi &=-\frac{1}{N_p}\int_{0}^{t}e\;dt \\ 
[\text{where}\; e &\text{is primary generated voltage}] \\ 
\text{or}\;\;  \phi  &=-\frac{1}{N_p}\int_{0}^{t}-(V_p)\;dt \\ 
 \phi &= \frac{1}{N_p}\int_{0}^{t}V \cos \omega t \;dt\\ 
 &= \frac{V}{\omega N_p}\sin \omega t\\ 
 &\text{Now reluctance} \\ 
 \Re &= \frac{N_p I \sin \omega t}{\frac{V}{\omega N_p} \sin \omega t}\\ 
 &= \frac{N_p^2\omega I}{V}\\
& \text{So mean radius,}\\
R&=\frac{N_p^2 \times \omega I \times \mu r^2}{2V}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 27 A 0-1 Ampere moving iron ammeter has an internal resistance of 50 m[latex]\Omega[/latex] and inductance of
0.1 mH. A shunt coil is connected to extend its range to 0-10 Ampere for all operating
frequencies. The time constant in milliseconds and resistance in m[latex]\Omega[/latex] of the shunt coil
respectively are
solution: Given, [latex]I_m=1A, [/latex] [latex]R_m=50m\Omega [/latex] [latex]L_m=0.1 mH, [/latex] [latex]I=10A [/latex] We know, [latex]R_{sh}=\frac{R_m}{(m-1)}; [/latex] [latex]m=\frac{I}{I_m}=\frac{10}{1}=10 [/latex] [latex]R_{sh}=\frac{50 \times 10^{-3}}{10-1}[/latex] [latex] \;\;=5.55m\Omega [/latex] For all frequencies time constant of shunt and meter arm should be equal. [latex]\begin{aligned} i.e. \;\; \frac{\omega L_m}{R_m} &=\frac{\omega L_{sh}}{R_{sh}} \\ \frac{L_m}{R_m} &= \frac{L_{sh}}{R_{sh}}\\ \frac{L_m}{R_m} &= \frac{0.1 \times 10^{-3}}{50 \times 10^{-3}}\\ &=0.002=2ms \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 28 The positive, negative and zero sequence impedances of a three phase generator are [latex]Z_{1},Z_{2}[/latex] and [latex] Z_{0}[/latex] respectively. For a line-to-line fault with fault impedance [latex]Z_{f}[/latex] ,the fault current is    [latex]I_{f1}=kI_{f}[/latex] , where [latex]I_{f}[/latex] is the fault current with zero fault impedance. The relation between [latex]Z_{f}[/latex] and k is
solution: For LL fault: Without [latex]Z_f[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given, } I_{f1}&=k \times I_f \\ \frac{\sqrt{3} E_g}{Z_1+Z_2+Z_f} &=\left ( \frac{\sqrt{3} E_g}{Z_1+Z_2} \right )k \\ Z_1+Z_2&=k(Z_1+Z_2+Z_f) \\ Z_f &=\frac{(Z_1+Z_2)(1-k)}{k} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 29 Consider the two bus power system network with given loads as shown in the figure. All
the values shown in the figure are in per unit. The reactive power supplied by generator [latex]G_1[/latex] and [latex]G_2[/latex] are [latex]Q_{G1}[/latex] and [latex]Q_{G2}[/latex] respectively. The per unit values of [latex]Q_{G1}, Q_{G2}[/latex], and line reactive
power loss ([latex]Q_{loss}[/latex]) respectively are
solution:
At [latex]G_2[/latex] load demand is 20 pu, [latex]G_2[/latex] supplies only 15 pu. Remaining supplied by [latex]G_1[/latex] through transmission line. [latex]\begin{aligned}
P_S&=\left | \frac{V_SV_R}{X_L} \right | \sin \delta \\
5&=\frac{1 \times 1}{0.1} \sin \delta \\
\delta &=30^{\circ}\\
Q_S&=\frac{V_S^2}{X_L}-\frac{V_SV_R}{X_L} \cos \delta \\
&=\frac{1^2}{0.1}-\frac{1 \times 1 }{0.1} \cos 30^{\circ}\\
&=1.34 p.u.\\
Q_R&=\left | \frac{V_SV_R}{X_L} \right | \cos \delta -\left | \frac{V_R^2}{X_L} \right | \\
5&=\frac{1 \times 1}{0.1} \cos 30^{\circ}-\frac{1^2}{0.1} \\
&=-1.34p.u.\\
Q_{loss}&+Q_S-Q_R\\
&=1.34-(-1.34)=2.68p.u.\\
\text{At }G_1: \; Q_{G1}&=Q_{load}+Q_S\\
&=5+1.34=6.34p.u.\\
\text{At }G_2: \; Q_{G2}&=Q_{load}-(-Q_R)\\
&=10-(-1.34)=11.34p.u.
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 30 The per-unit power output of a salient-pole generator which is connected to an infinite bus,
is given by the expression,  [latex]P= 1.4 \sin\delta + 0.15 \sin 2 \delta[/latex], where [latex]\delta[/latex] is the load angle. Newton-Raphson method is used to calculate the value of [latex]\delta[/latex] for P = 0.8 pu. If the initial guess is
30[latex]^{\circ}[/latex], then its value (in degree) at the end of the first iteration is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} P(\delta )&=1.4 \sin \delta +0.15 \sin 2\delta =0.8\\ &=1.4 \sin \delta +0.15 \sin 2\delta -0.8=0\\ P'(\delta )&=\frac{d}{d\delta }(P(\delta ))\\ &=1.4 \cos \delta +0.30 \cos 2\delta \text{Given, } \delta _0&=30^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex] By using Newton Raphson method for single variable, [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta \delta &=\delta _1-\delta _0=-\frac{f(\delta _0)}{f'(\delta_0)}=-\frac{P(\delta _0)}{P'(\delta_0)}\\ &=\delta _1 -30^{\circ}=-\frac{1.4 \sin 30^{\circ}+0.15 \sin 60^{\circ} -0.8}{1.4 \cos 30^{\circ}+0.3 \cos 60^{\circ}}\\ &=\delta _1 -30^{\circ}=-0.0219 \; red =-1.26^{\circ}\\ &=\delta _1 =28.74^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 31 A DC voltage source is connected to a series L-C circuit by turning on the switch S at time t=0 as shown in the figure. Assume i(0)=0, v(0)=0. Which one of the following
circular loci represents the plot of i(t) versus v(t) ?
solution: [latex]I(s)=\frac{\frac{5}{s}}{s+\frac{1}{s}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{5}{s^2+1} [/latex] [latex]i(t)=5 \sin t [/latex] [latex]v(t)=\frac{1}{C}\int_{0}^{t}i \; dt [/latex] [latex]v(t)=\int_{0}^{t}5 \sin t \; dt [/latex] [latex]v(t)=5[-\cos t]_0^t [/latex] [latex]v(t)=5[-\cos t+1] [/latex] [latex]v(t)=5-5 \cos t[/latex] [latex]\begin{matrix} t & i(t) & v(t)\\ 0 & 0 & 0\\ \frac{T}{4} & 5 & 5\\ \frac{T}{2}& 0 & 10\\ \frac{3T}{4} &-5 & 5\\ T& 0 & 0 \end{matrix}[/latex]

question: Question 32 The equivalent impedance [latex]Z_{eq}[/latex] for the infinite ladder circuit shown in the figure is
solution: [latex]Z_1=j9 [/latex] [latex]Z_2=j5-j1=j4 [/latex] [latex]Z_{eq}=Z_1+\frac{Z_2Z_{eq}}{Z_2+Z_{eq}} [/latex] By solving above equation, [latex]Z_{eq}=j12[/latex]

question: Question 33 Consider a system governed by the following equations [latex]\frac{dx_{1}(t)}{dt}=x_{2}(t)-x_{1}(t)[/latex] [latex] \frac{dx_{2}(t)}{dt}=x_{1}(t)-x_{2}(t)[/latex] The initial conditions are such that [latex]x_{1} \lt x_{2}(0) \lt \infty[/latex]. Let [latex]x_{1f}=\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }x_{1}(t)[/latex] and [latex]x_{2f}=\lim_{t\rightarrow \infty }x_{2}(t)[/latex]. Which one of the following is true?
Question 34 The number of roots of the polynomial, [latex]s^{7}+s^{6}+7s^{5}+14s^{4}+31s^{3}+73s^{2}+25s+200[/latex], in the open left half of the complex plane is
solution: Characteristic equation, [latex]s^7+s^6+7s^5+14s^4+31s^3+73s^2+25s+200=0[/latex] Auxillary equation, [latex]A(s)=8s^4+48s^2+200 [/latex] [latex]\frac{d}{ds}A(s)=32s^3+96s[/latex] Total number of poles =7 Two sign change above auxillary equation=2 poles in RHS. Two sign changes below auxillary equation implies out of 4 symmetric roots about origin, two poles are in LHS and two poles are in RHS. Therefore 3 poles in LHS and 4 poles in RHS.

question: Question 35 If C is a circle |z|=4 and  [latex]f(z)=\frac{z^{2}}{(z^{2}-3z+2)^{2}}[/latex], then [latex]\oint_{C}f(z)dz[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} &\int \frac{z^2}{(z^2-3z+2)^2}dz\\ &\int \frac{z^2}{(z-1)^2(z-2)^2}dz\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Res. }f(z)_{z=1}&=\lim_{z \to 1}\frac{1}{1!}\frac{d}{dz} \left ((z-1)^2\frac{z^2}{(z-1)^2(z-2)^2} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 1}\left (\frac{2z(z-2)^2-2z^2(z-2)}{((z-2)^4} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 1}\left (\frac{2z(z-2)-2z^2}{((z-2)^3} \right )=\frac{-4}{-1}=4\\ \text{Res. }f(z)_{z=2}&=\lim_{z \to 2}\frac{1}{1!}\frac{d}{dz} \left ((z-2)^2\frac{z^2}{(z-1)^2(z-2)^2} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 2}\left (\frac{(z-1)^2\cdot 2z-z^22(z-1)}{((z-1)^4} \right )\\ &=\lim_{z \to 2}\left (\frac{2z(z-1)-2z^2}{((z-1)^3} \right )=\frac{4-8}{1}=-4\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] By residue theorem, [latex]I=2 \pi i (4-4)=0[/latex]

question: Question 36 Which one of the following statements is true about the digital circuit shown in the figure
solution: So, frequency will be divided by 5.

options.A: It can be used for dividing the input frequency by 3.
options.B: It can be used for dividing the input frequency by 5.
options.C: It can be used for dividing the input frequency by 7.
options.D: It cannot be reliably used as a frequency divider due to disjoint internal cycles.

question:
Question 37 Digital input signals A,B,C with A as the MSB and C as the LSB are used to realize the
Boolean function [latex]F=m_{0}+m_{2}+m_{3}+m_{5}+m_{7}, \; where \; m_{i}[/latex] denotes the [latex]i^{th}[/latex] minterm. In addition, F has a don't care for [latex]m_1[/latex]. The simplified expression for F is given by
solution: Given, [latex]f=m_0+m_2+m_3+m_5+m_7[/latex] and [latex]m_1=[/latex] don't care

question: Question 38 Consider the two continuous-time signals defined below: [latex]x_{1}(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} |t|, & -1\leq t \leq 1 \\ 0 & otherwise \end{matrix}\right. [/latex], [latex] x_{2}(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1-|t|, & -1\leq t \leq 1\\ 0, & otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] These signals are sampled with a sampling period of T=0.25 seconds to obtain discretetime signals [latex]x_{1}[n] \; and \; x_{2}[n][/latex], respectively. Which one of the following statements is true?
solution: [latex]x_1(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} |t|, & -1 \leq t \leq 1\\ 0, & \text{ otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]T_s=[/latex] sampling time-period = 0.25 sec [latex]x_1(n)=\{ 1,0.75,0.5,0.25,0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1\}[/latex] [latex]x_2(t)=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1-|t|, & -1 \leq t \leq 1\\ 0, & \text{ otherwise} \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] [latex]x_2(n)=\{  0,0.25,0.5,0.75,1,0.75,0.5,0.25,0\}[/latex] Since, [latex]x_1(n)[/latex] is having one more non-zero sample of amplitude '1' as compared to [latex]x_2(n)[/latex]. Therefore, energy of [latex]x_1(n)[/latex] greater than energy of [latex]x_2(n)[/latex].

options.A: The energy of [latex]x_{1}[n][/latex] is greater than the energy of [latex]x_{2}[n][/latex]
options.B: The energy of [latex]x_{1}[n][/latex] is greater than the energy of [latex]x_{2}[n][/latex]
options.D: Neither [latex]x_{1}[n] nor x_{2}[n][/latex] is a finite-energy signal

question:
Question 39 The signal energy of the continuous-time signal [latex]
x(t) =[(t -1) u(t -1)][/latex] [latex]-[(t -2)u(t -2)][/latex] [latex]-[(t -3)u(t -3)][/latex]  [latex]+[(t -4)u(t -4)][/latex] is
solution: [latex]x(t)=r(t-1)-r(t-2)-r(t-3)+r(t-4)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} Ex(t)&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }|x(t)|^2 dt \\ &=\int_{1}^{2}|(t-1)^2| dt +\int_{2}^{3}1^2 dt\\&+\int_{3}^{4}(-(t-4))^2dt\\ &= \frac{1}{3}+1+\frac{1}{3}=\frac{5}{3} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 The Fourier transform of a continuous-time signal x(t) is given by [latex]X(\omega )=\frac{1}{(10+j\omega )^{2}},-\infty \lt \omega \lt  \infty[/latex], where  [latex] j=\sqrt{-1} \; and \; \omega[/latex] denotes frequency. Then the value of |lnx(t)| at t=1 is ___________ (up to 1 decimal place). ( ln denotes the logarithm to base e )
solution: [latex]x(t)\rightleftharpoons X(j\omega )=\frac{1}{(10+j\omega )^2}[/latex] By taking inverse Fourier transform, [latex]\begin{aligned} x(t)&=te^{-10t}u(t) \\ \text{Now, } x(t)_{t=1}&= 1 \times e^{-10} \times 1=e^{-10}\\ \text{Thus, }|\ln (x(t))| &= |\ln (e^{-10})|=|-10|=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 In the circuit shown in the figure, the bipolar junction transistor (BJT) has a current gain [latex]\beta=100[/latex]. The base-emitter voltage drop is a constant, [latex]V_{BE}= 0.7[/latex] V. The value of the The venin equivalent resistance [latex]R_{Th}[/latex] (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) as shown in the figure is ______ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution:
To calculate [latex]R_{Th}[/latex] D.C. volatage should be short circuited. [latex]R_{Th}=1k\Omega ||\frac{10k}{1+\beta } [/latex] [latex]
\; \; =1k\Omega ||99.0099 [/latex] [latex]
R_{Th}=90.09\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 42 As shown in the figure, C is the arc from the point (3,0) to the point (0,3) on the circle [latex]x^{2}+y^{2}=9[/latex]. The value of the integral [latex]\int_{C}(y^{2}+2yx)dx+(2xy+x^{2})dy[/latex] is _____ (up to 2
decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} x^2+y^2&=9\\ x&=3 \cos \theta \\ y&=3 \sin \theta \\ dx&=-3 \sin \theta \; d\theta\\ dy&=3 \cos \theta \;d\theta \end{aligned} [/latex] [latex]\theta[/latex] varies from 0 to [latex]\frac{\pi}{2}[/latex] [latex] \int (y^2+2xy)dx+(2xy+x^2)dy =\int_{0}^{\pi/2}(9 \sin ^2 \theta +18 \sin \theta \cos \theta )(-3 \sin \theta d\theta )+(18 \sin \theta \cos \theta +9 \cos ^2 \theta )(3 \cos \theta )d\theta [/latex] [latex]=\int_{0}^{\pi/2}(-27\sin ^3 \theta -54 \sin ^2 \theta \cos \theta +54 \sin \theta \cos ^2 \theta +27 \cos ^3 \theta )d\theta =0[/latex]

question: Question 43 Let [latex]f(x)=3x^{3}-7x^{2}+5x+6[/latex]. The maximum value of f(x) over the interval [0, 2] is _______ (up to 1 decimal place).

Question 44 Let [latex]A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0&-1 \\ -1&2 & 0\\ 0& 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] and [latex]B=A^{3}-A^{2}-4A+5I[/latex], where I is the 3x3 identity matrix. The
determinant of B is ________ (up to 1 decimal place).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & -1\\ -1 &2 &0 \\ 0 & 0 & -2 \end{bmatrix}\\ |A-\lambda I|=0\\ \begin{bmatrix} 1-\lambda & 0& -1\\ -1& 2-\lambda & 0\\ 0 & 0 &-2-\lambda \end{bmatrix}=0\\ (1-\lambda )((2-\lambda )(-2-\lambda ))-1(0-0)=0\\ \lambda =1,2,-2\\ \text{Eigen value of A are 1,2,-2}\\ \text{Eigen value of } A^3 \text{ are 1,8,-8}\\ \text{Eigen value of } A^2 \text{ are 1,4,4}\\ \text{Eigen value of } 4A \text{ are 4,8,-8}\\ \text{Eigen value of } 5I \text{ are 5,5,5}\\ A^3-A^2-4A+5I \text{ are 1,1,1}\\ \therefore \;\; |B|=(1)(1)(1)=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 45 The capacitance of an air-filled parallel-plate capacitor is 60 pF. When a dielectric slab
whose thickness is half the distance between the plates, is placed on one of the plates
covering it entirely, the capacitance becomes 86 pF.Neglecting the fringing effects, the
relative permittivity of the dielectric is _____________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given, [latex]C=\frac{\varepsilon _0A}{d}=60pF[/latex] In second case: Capacitance, [latex]\begin{aligned} C_1 &=\frac{\varepsilon _0A}{d/2} =\frac{2\varepsilon _0A}{d}\\ &= 2 \times (60 pF)=120pF\\ C_2&=\frac{2\varepsilon _0\varepsilon _rA}{d} \\ &=(2 \times 60)\varepsilon _r \;pF =120\varepsilon _r \; pF\\ C_{eq}&=\frac{C_1C_2}{C_1+C_2}=\frac{120 \times 120\varepsilon _r}{(120+120\varepsilon _r)}pF \\ &= 86\;pF \;\;(given)\\ 86&=\frac{120 \times 120\varepsilon _r}{120(1+\varepsilon _r)} \\ \frac{86}{120}&= \frac{\varepsilon _r}{1+\varepsilon _r}\\ \varepsilon _r &=\frac{86}{34}=2.53 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 The unit step response y(t) of a unity feedback system with open loop transfer function [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K}{(s+1)^{2}(s+2)}[/latex] is shown in the figure. The value of K is _______ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Closed loop transfer function, [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{\frac{K}{(s+1)^2(s+2)}}{1+\frac{K}{(s+1)^2(s+2)}} [/latex] [latex]\frac{C(s)}{R(s)}=\frac{K}{(s+1)^2(s+2)+K} [/latex] Given [latex] R(s)=\frac{1}{s} [/latex] [latex]C(s)=\frac{K}{s((s+1)^2(s+2)+K)} [/latex] [latex]\lim_{s \to 0}sC(s)=0.8 [/latex] [latex]\frac{K}{2+K}=0.8 [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \; K=8[/latex]

question: Question 47 A three-phase load is connected to a three-phase balanced supply as shown in the figure. If [latex]V_{an}=100\angle 0^{\circ} V[/latex], [latex]V_{bn}=100\angle -120^{\circ}V[/latex] and [latex]V_{cn}=100\angle -240^{\circ} V[/latex] (angles are considered positive in the anti-clockwise direction), the value of R for zero current in the neutral wire is ___________[latex]\Omega[/latex] (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: From the given voltages, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_R&=\frac{V_{RN}}{R}=\frac{100\angle 0^{\circ}}{R}\\ I_Y&=\frac{V_{YN}}{jX_L}=\frac{100\angle 120^{\circ}}{j10}\\ &= 10\angle -210^{\circ}\\ I_B&=\frac{V_{BN}}{-jX_C}=\frac{100\angle -240^{\circ}}{-j10}\\ &=10\angle -150^{\circ}\\ \text{For }\; I_N&=0\\ I_R+I_Y+I_B&=0\\ \frac{100}{R}+&10\angle -210^{\circ}+10\angle -150^{\circ}=0\\ R&=5.77\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 The voltage across the circuit in the figure, and the current through it, are given by the
following expressions: [latex]v(t) = 5 - 10 cos(\omega t + 60^{\circ}) V [/latex] [latex]i(t) = 5 + X cos(\omega t) A[/latex] where [latex]\omega =100 \pi[/latex] radian/s. If the average power delivered to the circuit is zero, then the
value of X (in Ampere) is _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Given that, [latex]v(t)=5-10 \cos (\omega t+60^{\circ}) [/latex] [latex]i(t)=5+C \cos (\omega t-0^{\circ}) [/latex] [latex]P_{req}=0 [/latex] [latex]0=5 \times 5 +\frac{1}{2}[(-10)(X)\cos(60^{\circ})] [/latex] [latex]-25=\frac{1}{2}[(-10)(X)\cos(60^{\circ})] [/latex] [latex]X=10[/latex]

question:
Question 49 A phase controlled single phase rectifier, supplied by an AC source, feeds power to an
R-L-E load as shown in the figure. The rectifier output voltage has an average value given
by [latex]V_{0}=\frac{V_{m}}{2 \pi}(3+ \cos \alpha),[/latex] where [latex]V_{m}=80\pi[/latex] volts and [latex]\alpha[/latex] is the firing angle. If the power delivered to the lossless battery is 1600 W, [latex]\alpha[/latex] in degree is________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&=\frac{V_m}{2 \pi}(3+\cos \alpha )\\ E_bI_0&=1600W\\ I_0&=\frac{1600}{80}=20A\\ V_0&=E_b+I_0R_a\\ \frac{V_m}{2 \pi}(3+\cos \alpha )&=80+(20 \times 2)\\ \frac{80 \pi}{2 \pi}(3+\cos \alpha )&=80+40\\ \alpha &=90^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 The figure shows two buck converters connected in parallel. The common input dc voltage
for the converters has a value of 100 V. The converters have inductors of identical value.
The load resistance is 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The capacitor voltage has negligible ripple. Both converters operate in the continuous conduction mode. The switching frequency is 1 kHz, and the switch control signals are as shown. The circuit operates in the steady state. Assuming that the converters share the load equally, the average value of [latex]i_{S1}[/latex], the current of switch S1 (in Ampere), is _____ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: Hence it is buck converter, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_0&=\alpha V_s\\ V_0&=0.5 \times 100=50V\\ I_0&=\frac{V_0}{R}=\frac{50}{1}=50A\\ V_sI_s&=V_0I_0\\ I_s&=\frac{V_0I_0}{V_s}=\frac{50\times 50}{100}=25A\\ I_{s1}&=I_{s2}=\frac{I_s}{2}=12.5A \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 51 A 3-phase 900kVA, [latex]3kV/\sqrt{3}kV(\Delta /Y)[/latex], 50Hz transformer has primary (high voltage side) resistance per phase of 0.3 [latex]\Omega[/latex] and secondary (low voltage side) resistance per phase of 0.02 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. Iron loss of the transformer is 10 kW. The full load % efficiency of the transformer operated at unity power factor is _______ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: [latex]900kVA, \Delta /Y, 3-[/latex]phase transformer [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Given,}\;\; R_1 &=300W/ph \\ R_2&= 0.02 W/ph\\ \text{Iron loss}&=10kW \end{aligned}[/latex] Primary line current, [latex]I_{l_1}=\frac{900 \times 1000}{\sqrt{3} \times 3000}=173.2A [/latex] Primary phase current, [latex]I_{ph_1}=100A[/latex] Secondary line current, [latex]I_{l_2}=\frac{900 \times 1000}{\sqrt{3} \times 1732}=300A[/latex] Secondary phase current [latex]I_{ph_2}=300A [/latex] Cu loss of H.V. side [latex]=3 \times I_1^2 R_1=3(100)^2 (0.3) =9000 Watts[/latex] Cu loss of L.V. side [latex]= 3 \times _2^2 \times R_2 =3(300)^2(0.02)=5400Watts [/latex] Full load efficiency at u.p.f. [latex]\begin{aligned} \eta &=\frac{1 \times 900 \times 1000 \times 1}{1 \times 900 \times 1000+9000+5400+10000} \\ &= \frac{900000}{924400}\\ \therefore \;\;\eta &=\eta 0.9736 \; \text{or} \; 97.36\% \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 52 A 200 V DC series motor, when operating from rated voltage while driving a certain load,
draws 10 A current and runs at 1000 r.p.m. The total series resistance is 1 [latex]\Omega[/latex]. The magnetic
circuit is assumed to be linear. At the same supply voltage, the load torque is increased by
44%. The speed of the motor in r.p.m. (rounded to the nearest integer) is ________ .
solution:
Form circuit diagram, [latex]\begin{aligned}
E_{b1} &=V-I_a(R_a+R_{se}) \\ 
 &= 200-10(1)=190V\\ 
 N_1&= 1000rpm
\end{aligned}[/latex] Load torque increased by 44%  [latex](T\propto I_a^2)[/latex] [latex]
\begin{aligned}
\therefore \; \frac{T_2}{T_1} &=\left ( \frac{I_{a2}}{I_{a1}} \right )^2 \\ 
\Rightarrow \;\; \frac{1.44T_1}{T_1} &=\left ( \frac{I_{a2}}{10} \right )^2  \\ 
 \therefore \;\; I_{a2}^2&= 144\\ 
 I_{a2}&= 12A\\ 
&\text{At same voltage,}\\
 E_{b2}&=V-I_{a2}(R_a+R_{se}) \\ 
\therefore \;\; E_{b2} &= 200-12(1)=188V\\ 
 &\text{For series motor,}\\ 
 N&\propto \frac{E_b}{\phi }\;\;(\phi \propto I_a) \\ 
 \frac{N_2}{N_1}&=\frac{E_{b2}}{E_{b1}} \times \frac{I_{a1}}{I_{a2}}\\ 
\frac{N_2}{1000} &=\frac{188}{190}\times \frac{10}{12} \\
N_2&=824.56\; \text{rpm}\\ 
&\simeq 825\; \text{rpm}
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 53 A dc to dc converter shown in the figure is charging a battery bank, B2 whose voltage is
constant at 150 V. B1 is another battery bank whose voltage is constant at 50 V. The value
of the inductor, L is 5 mH and the ideal switch, S is operated with a switching frequency of
5 kHz with a duty ratio of 0.4. Once the circuit has attained steady state and assuming the
diode D to be ideal, the power transferred from B1 to B2 (in Watt) is ___________ (up to 2
decimal places). .
solution:
During [latex]T_{on}[/latex] the circuit behaves as, [latex]\begin{aligned} V_s&=L\frac{di}{dt} \\ di&=\frac{V_s}{L}dt \end{aligned}[/latex] Integrating on both sides, [latex]\begin{aligned} I_P&=\frac{V_s}{L}T_{on}\\ T_{on}&=\alpha T=\frac{\alpha }{f}=80 \times 10^{-6}s\\ I_P&=\frac{50}{5 \times 10^{-3}}\times (80 \times 10^{-6})\\ &=0.8A \end{aligned}[/latex] During [latex]T_{off}[/latex], it is [latex]T_{on}\leq t\leq \beta T[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned}
\text{KVL,  } V_L&=V_s-V_0 \\ 
 (V_L)_{avg}&=0 \\ 
V_sT_{on}+&(V_s-V_0)(\beta T-T_{on}) =0 \\ 
V_s\beta T &=V_0(\beta T-T_{on}) \\ 
 \frac{V_0}{V_s}&=\frac{\beta }{\beta -\alpha } \\ 
 \beta &=0.6\\
&\text{Fromt the graph of } i_L, \\
I_{L(avg)}&=\frac{\frac{1}{2} \times b \times h}{T}\\
&=\frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \beta T \times I_P}{T}\\
&=\frac{1}{2} \times 0.6 \times 0.8=0.24A\\
&\text{Power transferred to } B_2 \text{ is,}\\
P&=V_s \times (I_L)_{avg}\\
  \text{ where } I_s&=I_L\\
P&=50 \times 0.24\\
&=12W
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 54 The equivalent circuit of a single phase induction motor is shown in the figure, where the
parameters are [latex]R_{1}=R'_{2}=X_{i1}=X'_{i2}=12\Omega [/latex], [latex]X_{M}=240\Omega[/latex] and s is the slip. At no-load, the motor speed can be approximated to be the synchronous speed. The no-load lagging power factor of the motor is___________ (up to 3 decimal places).
solution: Simplifying the above circuit into a simple R-L circuit, [latex]\begin{aligned} Z_{eq} &=\frac{(3+j6)(j120)}{(3+j126)}+(12+j32) \\ &=138.563\angle \\ &\text{Current drawn by motor is } \\ I&= \frac{V\angle 0}{Z\angle \theta } \end{aligned} [/latex] ([latex]\therefore \; \theta :[/latex]  impedance angle will be p.f. angle) [latex] \therefore[/latex] No laod lagging p.f. of motor is [latex](\cos\theta ),[/latex] [latex] \cos(83.9)=0.106[/latex] lagging power factor

question:
Question 55 The voltage v(t) across the terminals a and b as shown in the figure, is a sinusoidal voltage
having a frequency [latex]\omega[/latex]=100 radian/s. When the inductor current i(t) is in phase with the
voltage v(t), the magnitude of the impedance Z (in [latex]\Omega[/latex]) seen between the terminals a and b
is ________ (up to 2 decimal places).
solution: At resonance imaginary part of [latex]Z_{eq}=0 [/latex] Real of [latex] Z_{eq}=\frac{R_1 X_c^2}{R_1^2+X-c^2} [/latex] [latex]\;\;=\frac{100 \times 100 \times 100}{100^2+100^2}=50\Omega[/latex]
